Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind is the end result of combining sci-fi and romance into a wholly original and superbly acted script. Joel (played with an every-man nuance by Jim Carrey in a way not seen since his turn on The Truman Show) breaks up with his girlfriend, Clementine (played by Kate Winslet with an artistic, indie girl charm) and decides to undergo an experimental procedure in which she is erased from his memories so that the post-breakup healing can commence without those pesky doubts and regrets that so often accompany the end of a relationship. The process itself is the bulk of the film and viewers are treated into glimpses of Joel's mind as Clementine is systematically deleted. It isn't until Joel is under and the procedure has began that he realizes that even though his breakup was difficult he was shaped by it, and losing all of those experiences (the good and the bad) would erase a part of himself. What results is Joel's attempts to hang on to what is important by fighting through the feelings that attach themselves to each piece of their relationship and fighting the efforts of those hired to purge these memories (Elijah Wood, Mark Ruffalo) while inside of the procedure. It's a beautiful film whose subject matter is complex enough to be engaging while being relatable enough to be sympathetic to either outcome. It's a modern classic detailing the entirety of a relationship in a completely original and captivating way that makes viewers consider their own experiences as the credits roll. A masterpiece of filmmaking.

"Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind" is a movie that uses the fragility of memory and hurt of love to show the desperate measures taken by a couple who decide to break up. After two years of living together, Introverted Joel Barrish ( Jim Carey ) and extrovert Clementine Kruczynski ( Kate Winslet ) undertake extreme procedures to erase any memory of each other. 

What director Michel Gondry and Writer Charlie Kaufman have created is a movie designed to slowly release forgotten incidents and emotions as the audience discover the film is running in reverse. Bearing witness to love's decay the audience are thrown sidelines with the introduction of Patrick ( Elijah Wood ) and Stan ( Mark Ruffalo ). Both Patrick and Stan work for Lacuna a private medical company with some rather dodgy practices regarding memory erasure. Along with Patrick and Stan, Mary ( Kirsten Dunst ) Stan's girlfriend is also a work colleague and joins the other two when they are tasked with erasing any memory of Clementine from Joel's mind. Patrick however uses information provided to Lacuna by both Joel and Clementine to manipulate Clementine in an attempt to get her to fall in love with him.

What ensues is a battle of the mind to try and save their relationship after discovering that all was not as bad as the couple believed. But with each recalled memory there is a doomed ending that ends up being erased. The only hope is to try and hide Clementine in an earlier non related memory in Joel's mind as Lacuna remove all traces of each other. The climax of the film comes with a surprise that complicates any post mind erasing procedures. 

"Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind" evokes real devastation in lost love and tells a fantasy tale of how we all try to erase those hurtful memories. However, after everything, our memories are all we really have, they make us who we are, once they are gone, we ourselves are surely gone.

This is perhaps the closest a movie has come to describing dreams with merely visuals. It also perfectly portrays the pain of loss especially in romantic relationships. The pace may be a bit slow, which plunges Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind into a small tide of mediocrity, but it still makes up for it in other areas. The script is very well-written, and incorporates "philosophical" elements in a natural way, in contrast to what usually happens when other movies do the same, to the point the movie's name was inspired by these elements and it didn't seem "fake" or forced at all. There's always a feel-good vibe, which is a paradox taking into consideration the situation during most of the movie. The direction is excellent and the actors show a certain level of maturity that meets the standards set by the plot, especially from Jim Carrey. On the other hand, Kate Winslet gets into the shoes of her character so meticulously and harmoniously, almost as if she was playing herself. And of course the two have memorable chemistry together, rendering the final result worthy of watching.

When I first saw Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, I wasn't expecting to love it, let alone like it. What a surprise when I saw it! I think this film is wonderful in every aspect, truly beautiful and packs a full emotional punch. In fact, if you don't mind me saying so, it is one of my favourite films of the 2000s.

I especially loved how Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind was shot. The whole film looks beautiful, not only with the cinematography which is indeed spellbinding but also in the scenery which was nothing short of amazing. Another impressive asset was the soundtrack/score. Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind doesn't have the best soundtrack/score I have ever heard in my life, but the score makes the film all the more moving, while the soundtrack is well selected and appropriate.

I was also very taken with the story. Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind has one beautifully constructed story I can tell you, with an almost poignant message about it. It is strange and bizarre yes, but neither of those are bad, quite the contrary. Then there is the script which is both poignant and funny, not to mention very deep. The pacing very rarely feels boring if at all, and the direction is adept.

I have very little to complain about Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind's performances either. As good as the supporting performances are especially from the always splendid Tom Wilkinson, I have to give the real kudos to the leads. Jim Carrey has done some good performances in some good films, The Mask, Liar Liar, The Cable Guy and Bruce Almighty showcase his comedy talents wonderfully, but this and The Truman Show show he is perfectly good at drama too. He is very understated here, but it works as he still manages to be likable all the same. The real star though is Kate Winslet. A beautiful and captivating actress, Winslet is absolutely perfect in her role.

Overall, wonderful film. Bizarre yes, but very tender and poignant helped by the exceptional performances and cinematography. 10/10 Bethany Cox

To name a few of them, when Joel (Jim Carrey) and Clementine (Kate Winslet) are under the blanket together, when they're in bed on the beach, the Grand Central scene, and, most notably, when Clem is saying goodbye to Joel as the beach-front house is crumbling behind her. *Side Note* This is the movie that introduced me to the name "Joel," which I named the protagonist to my first novel. The plot is clever, but not confusing. It's smart and layered, but not pretentious. There's also an excellent sub-plot concerning the Lacuna Co.'s doctor (Tom Wilkinson) and the receptionist (Kirsten Dunst), which shows how the procedure can be abused and ineffective. The effects hold-up and brilliantly portray what erasing a memory might look like. It also contains hints of creepiness, with blank, contorted faces like something out of The Ring. The ending answers its own question for its protags, but poses one for the viewers: If you heard everything your (ex)partner had to say about you before they erased you from their memory, would give it another shot? I like the answer we get for Joel and Clem.

A few minutes into Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, it becomes evident that is from a script by Charlie Kaufman and this is a good thing.  As always with Kaufman, it is an insanely original, challenging, thought-provoking and ultimately rewarding viewing experience.  It's the story of the relationship between free-spirited but unstable Clementine (Kate Winslet) and reserved Joel (Jim Carrey).  When the relationship starts to go stale, Clementine has her memory of Joel erased by a company specializing in the unique procedure.  It's a story of loss and what we value in a relationship – the memories of good times or the value of the relationship at the moment we experience it?  Michel Gondry's direction can be distracting and inconsistent at times, but the refreshingly subdued performance by Carrey and Winslet's contagious charm make the film worth watching.

Michel Gondry's "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind" is an original, heartwarming and deeply touching sci-fi romance that showcases Charlie Kaufmann's mind-bending strengths as a screenwriter. With his second feature, French filmmaker Michel Gondry created a mesmerizing mind-bending romance that's stood test of time as a modern-day classic. Using captivating cinematography, Gondry draws viewers into the ill-fated romance between two star-crossed lovers that erase each other from their memories. Gondry's decision to shoot the movie using handheld cinematography is risky, but it works immensely. It lends palpable tension and unnerving panic to the movie, giving viewers sensations of how it truly feels to lose one's most precious memories of lovers. Gondry exhibits impressive control over production design, editing and musical score, using these elements to create an unforgettable cinematic experience. Charlie Kaufman's script is also sensational, and expertly uses a nonlinear narrative to convey psychological trauma faced by an ill-fated couple that lose each other's memories. It's hard to not praise phenomenal performances from the cast. Jim Carrey delivers one of his best career performances as Joel Barish. With mesmerizing expressions, he conveys the frustrations, sexual jealousy and lifelong regrets of an introverted writer that strives to erase his former girlfriend from his memory. Kate Winslet is equally astonishing in the role of a free-spirited woman that openly rejects men in her life. The film Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind produced by Michel Gondry and Charlie Kaufman in 2004 contains several key themes, including memory, identity, and romance. The plot revolves around Joel Barish, a single male suffering from a dysfunctional association with Kruczynski. As their relationship breaks down, both choose to erase each other's memories. As the movie progresses, Joel confesses to the audience that even though he is depressed, he starts regretting his consent to the medical procedure and desperately attempts to hang onto the jovial instances in his life (Gondry et al., 2004). Therein, smell and sight appear as two of the most reliable human senses that correlate with one's memory. Kaufman tends to complicate the script in his motion pictures, and this presentation is no exception. For instance, the narrators tell the story in a reverse fashion, which assists in hiding some information from the viewers. Kaufman and Gondry use this strategy to reveal their forgotten emotions gradually.
	Some of the philosophical questions that emerge in this film are whether human beings are a sum of their memories or only a compilation of experiences, and whether the process of erasing an incident from the human brain has any benefits. In the movie, the proposal of forgetting some episodes promises to increase one's happiness. The alternative is that eliminating the incident could deteriorate the mental functioning and further complicate the characters' life. Consequently, they will not have learned anything from such an experience or realize any improvement. The motion picture eventually concludes that cleaning the human mind will not result in the proverbial eternal sunshine. The fundamental aspect of this theory is that people needed to ask themselves questions regarding whether they would make the same decision for eternity before acting. When they pose them, the query presents the brain with the potential for new possibilities. Nietzsche presents the case of the greatness of action and dignity to people who accept their decisions for all eternity. The characters do not learn any lessons from their troubles and only opt for the slow and dull life refusing to entertain an alternate lifestyle (Smith, 2016). From the movie, it is evident that Joel and Clementine fit into the Nietzschean description squarely because they are pure individuals who avoid any form of anguish. The main message of the motion picture is that love is flawed because it is an outcome of an imperfect human being. This feeling is linked to people; therefore, when they enter a relationship, they are already bound to have issues. 
The film is surprisingly lacking in plot twists and sudden disclosures concerning the relationships. However, the producers display an outdated view of love's demise. The "Eternal Sunshine" is different from Kaufman's earlier works because he fails to impress the audience with original stunts. The opening credits for "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind" don't occur for about fifteen minutes. The first fifteen minutes shows the start (or it appears to) of a quirky relationship between Joel (Jim Carrey) and Clementine (Kate Winslet). For someone who hasn't read anything about the film, or hasn't heard too much of what it's about, you expect this to be the start of their relationship. If you have not seen the film, stop now, and either see it and return, or see it and don't return. If you're here at all you've shown interest in one way or another, I hope. 

Most people should be able to relate to "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind" in one way or another. It is about the love and stress in an average relationship, including the thought of having children, the frustration of each other's company at times, and the cute inside jokes that couples often share. Kate Winslet and Jim Carrey do a wonderful job at convincing us they are for real. They're great at convincing us of their love, and they're great at convincing us of their growing aggravation of each other. 

So yes, on one level, the film is about the best and worst of being in a relationship with someone you can't stand to love. However, "Eternal Sunshine" is also a mind-bending science fiction film. This is not for shock value nor is it for a reason unrelated to the general themes and ideas expressed. It's done for a perfectly plausible reason, it allows a deeper understanding of the characters, and a wonderful look into what love is.

After the opening credits, and the quirky meeting of Joel and Clementine, the film seems (pay attention to the choice of words, 'seem') to have progressed some time. Joel is crying over Clementine, and he explains to his neighbors that she appears to no longer recognize who he is. Soon after, he finds out she really doesn't remember who he is - her memory has been altered to completely forget who Joel is. New, state of the art technology has allowed this to happen. 

This is not something that seems at all out of place in the film, and it seems to be easily accepted by audiences. It feels as natural as any normal, everyday technology would, due to the thought behind the explanation of it, and the realistic aspects of the workplace that this mind-erasing place is. Joel, upon learning of Clementine's decision to erase him from her memory, decides to do the same. From this point until the very end, most of the film takes place in Joel's mind, as the erasers go memory to memory, getting rid of all thoughts of Clementine.

This allows the audience to trace the relationship back to the beginning. Where did they go wrong? What has caused the trouble? Joel ends up falling for Clem all over again, and doesn't want the process to continue. It's a really thought-provoking idea topped with wonderful acting, beautiful chemistry between our two main characters, and great thoughts about love and human emotion. The film is also very clever and funny, at times that are necessary, and touchingly sad and romantic. 

After the process, despite their best efforts to salvage the memories (the lovely memories), Joel and Clem are both out of each other's lives. Well, so we have thought. The beginning of the film, the spontaneous meeting on the train, is actually taking place after the mind-erasing process for both Joel and Clem. This is a beautiful realization for the audience, because we now know the power of their love (cheesy, but true) and the nature of humans regarding love for each other. Love always wins. 

After a night on the frozen lake, Clem asks Joel to spend the night at his place, as shown in the beginning and again at the end. She discovers the tapes recorded before the operation (or process, or whatever you'd like to call it), and they both listen as they describe the things they hated about each other, the things they grew to hate over the course of two years. They listen, they wonder about their current state, and how they decide they cannot see anything they don't like about the other. 

"But you will."

....

"Okay."

"Okay."

This scene is absolutely perfect for the conclusion: it shows they have decided to put up with each other's issues, and have proceeded to be in love for as long as reality will let them be in love. It's a wonderful ending to an even more wonderful movie.

"If you could go back and change one thing in your past, what would it be?" How many times have you heard that question posed? If you had the chance to erase something painful, or awkward, or tragic from your past, would you take that opportunity? That is the question that floats at the center of Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind.

There are two trains of thought. One the one hand, removing the bad memory could be a good thing. Living without a certain pain or heartbreak could make life easier, simpler, bearable. When asked the, "If you could change one thing..." question, it's impossible not to relive a hundred memories that would be easier to deal with if they were different. Changing one extremely painful moment is an undeniably attractive option.

There is a second school of thought of course, the school of thought that says all of our failures and tragedies make us the people we are today. Removing even one memory would lessen or change us to our core. This mindset believes that our failures, not our successes, make us grow. This mindset is explored by Joel Barish.

Joel is in love, or was in love, or is falling in love, it is never entirely clear. He meets Clementine, a woman as eccentric as her name would suggest. They form a relationship that lasts two years, but when it comes to an end, it does not resolve amicably. Both Joel and Clementine separately decide to use a firm called Lacuna to erase their memories of each other. Halfway through the process, Joel realizes that he might not want to live without the memory of Clementine.

One of the most appealing aspects of the film is the attitude with which it is brought to the screen. Directed by Michael Gondry and written by the always imaginative Charlie Kaufman, the movie walks to the beat of its own drum. There is a freshness to the filmmaking that is absolutely engrossing. Truth be told, when I watched this movie, I was running on three hours of sleep over the past thirty-six hours. And yet, I was enthralled by the story (and the storytelling) from start to finish. The film does an excellent job of keeping the audience guessing, leading to a distinct lack of watch-checking throughout.

So, I was captivated by the story, my thoughts were provoked by the message(s), but I am still partially torn on the movie. I can't bring myself to decide whether the movie simply has what it takes to be great, or if it has that little extra something to make it amazing. Is it a four star movie, or a four and a half star movie? I'm still not entirely convinced one way or the other.

The only thing preventing me from fully committing to unmitigated love for Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind is "young Joel." There are a couple scenes in the middle of the movie that feature Jim Carrey playing a younger version of himself. Carrey's adult form is literally shrunk to child size, and the visual effect, coupled with these scenes purpose in the film, can't help but feel hokey and out-of-place. Taking these scenes out of the equation, the movie is such an infectious blend of imagination, romance, and drama. But these scenes lend the film an aspect of goofiness that feels entirely detached from the remainder of the narrative.

Whether it's Jack Black in Bernie, Steve Carell in Foxcatcher, or Jim Carrey in this movie, I absolutely love being surprised by dramatic performances from comedic actors (or vice versa). Carrey's performance as Joel is, above all else, restrained. The character is a homebody, conservative, subdued, soft-spoken ... everything we have come not to expect from Jim Carrey. I was equally impressed with the actor's performance in The Truman Show, but there is a level of subtlety in Joel that I have never seen from Carrey before. Honestly, I found that I identified with Joel more than any other film character in recent memory.

In a movie starring Jim Carrey and Kate Winslet, one would assume that Carrey would give the fun, peculiar performance. But no, it is Winslet who gets to let loose with a wonderfully unexpected turn. Kate Winslet is, perhaps, at her best when she is not restricted by the trappings of a period drama. And here, she is more uninhibited than she has ever been. The chemistry she shares with Jim Carrey never fails to bring a smile. I think the movie is so special, in part, due to the flipping of the assumed roles between Carrey and Winslet.

The supporting cast offers its own set of pleasures. The opening credits reveal that Mark Ruffalo, Tom Wilkinson, Kirsten Dunst, and Elijah Wood all lend their talents. There is nary a weak link in the cast, with Dunst and Ruffalo sharing an especially well-acted scene near the end of the film.

If a film requires a Jon Brion-esque score, it is best to hire Jon Brion. The style of Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind lends itself entirely to the composer's music. He provides a delightful little score! The very brief "Elephant Parade" cue is so wonderful, in the movie and out.

Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind is poetic in the delivery of its message. It features career subversive performances by Jim Carrey and Kate Winslet. The script by Charlie Kaufman and the filmmaking by Michael Gondry is inspired, while only falling into needless eccentricity for a few brief scenes. Time will tell if I can eventually peg the film as a masterpiece. But as it stands, the movie is a delightful example of marvelous filmmaking, teetering on the edge of genius.

Review In A Nutshell:

Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind is a story about a man who wants to erase the memories of his recent girlfriend through the help of scientists who specialise on this type of procedures.

Before coming into this film, I was sceptic in thinking that this would win me over as, though I am a fan of romantic stories even in their most clichÃ© levels, it always ran through my mind that this film probably wouldn't hit me the same way that films like 500 Days of Summer or When Harry Met Sally did. I couldn't pinpoint what it is in my mind that made me believe this as I never truly gave it any thought, but it could be because it is written by Charlie Kaufman, who didn't really impress me with his work on Spike Jonze's Adaptation even if I was a bit impressed with its ambition. This film surprised me, Kaufman has delivered a plot that may seem difficult to comprehend on paper but easy to understand on screen, the overall credit for this of course cannot only be given to the writer as this was also supported by Michel Gondry's direction and the performances from the actors. The film was able to keep my attention with its ability to deliver and draw out emotions; almost all areas of the film display some sort of genuine emotion, relying on the grace of the art of filmmaking rather than exhibit it in a conspicuous fashion. The film lets us be observers of their romance, but it takes us to a much deeper level where we get into the feelings that could only be felt when one is an unconscious state, Kaufman was clever enough to understand this as when the audience are able to break that barrier and cross to the other side, they are able to create that connection with the characters and identify with them; this concept also provided the opportunity for the director and Kaufman to sketch a story in a unique way which could also allow for repeated viewings without it feeling tiresome.

The film had me thinking repeatedly on how I would feel if I was placed in the protagonist's, Joel Barish, situation where my memory would be erased? In the middle of the process would I feel regret or would I be glad? As I am writing this, I think back in all the great and awful memories I had with certain individuals in my life, I cannot say that I regret any of it as I can understand that those experiences defined me and at certain points those people did make me happy, I wouldn't want to trade those memories away just to erase the bad ones, or else I would feel empty; which was the reason why I felt sorrowful of his memories being erased one by one.

If I had to nit-pick an issue that I had with the film's story, it would be the scene with Joel hiding under the table; this scene arrived suddenly with a slight change of tone which had me stepping back a bit. It slid from romantically dramatic to comedy without a buffer in between. 

The film's photography has this ethereal hand-held third person quality to it that definitely places the audience in the appropriate mindset from the start of the film. Once we get into the procedure, the imagery becomes more intense and interesting; it shows wonderful use of set design and CGI that it becomes hard to even see the strings being pulled by the artists.

The score in this film was light and tender but still with a hint of melancholy to parallel with the fragility of the situation. It was clear that it wasn't Jon Brion's, the composer, intention to have us be manipulated into pushing out tears but rather to understand the characters and to gain a sense of feel for the atmosphere that the film is trying to capture; we are propelled into an area of the mind where reality and logic aren't the primary principles. There is a particular track that I want to praise and it's called Elephant Parade, it may be short but it is so beautiful and gentle, I haven't felt so touched by an original score since Thomas Newman's piece at the end of Road to Perdition.

Jim Carrey as Joel Barish was phenomenal. His performance has shown a side of me from Carrey that I never thought existed, it makes me reflect on why he now only attempts to choose slapstick comedic roles when he can demonstrate such warmth and affection to his characters. Carrey was even able to outperform Kate Winslet in this film, and she is one of those actresses that always seem to impress me in anything she involves herself in. Carrey's best scene was at the end of the film at a house on a beach, where he has an intimate scene with Winslet cherishing their moment together. Kate Winslet was great in her role as the eccentric Clementine Kruczynski. This was also a side of her I have yet seen, as I seem to always identify her as this mature and well-composed woman despite the age in the role she plays; there is this youthful quality to her that one can't help but smile at. The supportive cast were also amazing, with performances from top tier actors like Tom Wilkinson, Mark Ruffalo, Kirsten Dunst and Elijah Wood; their performances didn't detract from the significance from the two lead actors, and instead elevated their performances.

Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind is a rare romance that doesn't require the superficiality of love to grab your attention, its strength is found within and the film slowly draws it out to the surface for us to savour. This is definitely a film I would easily find myself coming back to in the future particularly during the stages in my life that closely resembles Joel and Clementine's joys and pains.

Most of this review could be seen as a spoiler, so if you haven't seen this film and don't know what happens in it, just do yourself a favor and watch it right now...I'll wait...I greatly enjoyed this movie, and the entire concept behind it. Who hasn't wished they could erase some unpleasant memories? The idea of erasing an entire person from your mind to save yourself the heart-breaking memories is just a brilliant concept for a film. Perhaps the most surprising part is, despite the fact that this is a film about the fallout from a break-up, somehow it ends up being a very romantic story. It's almost one of those films that teaches that 2 soul mates are destined to be together. The framing of the film is a nice way of adding some intrigue to the beginning, I can only imagine how puzzling that would have felt if I didn't know the premise of the movie going in. Then a massive part of the movie takes place within the mind of Joel. I love the magic of the switch that takes place in the film once Joel hits the positive memories of Clementine. The idea that he suddenly has this change of heart, but is incapable of stopping the erasure is really well-played. I love the cat-and-mouse game he then starts to play with the technicians in his own brain.

Jim Carrey is actually a very good actor in my opinion, and this proves he can do drama. His heart-break is so genuine, that I fully believe he is on the verge of tears. You'd think Jim Carrey as a quiet introvert would be the biggest miscast in cinema history, but I think he nails it. In fact, as an overly introverted person myself, I have to say his portrayal of Joel kind of reminds me of me. So if you're going to cast crazy Jim Carrey as an introvert, who do you cast as the wacky extrovert Clementine? Why sweet little Kate Winslet, of course. I'm not 100% sold that Winslet fully captured the impulsive craziness of Clementine, but her performance is solid. Also, having someone as charming as Winslet in the lead really helps when they make the turn and we are supposed to see why Joel wants so desperately to hold onto Clementine. Then there's the crazy cast of technicians doing the procedure. Kirsten Dunst is very good as Mary. I liked her overly kind demeanor because then the crush feel like a natural result of her personality, which makes the reveal later in the film all the more surprising. Also, she cries very convincingly which is a hard thing for many actresses to do. Tom Wilkinson was also quite good as the man behind the magic. He has a comforting demeanor, so you can see why people who live in a world like ours might be convinced by him that this far-fetched procedure was real. My big problem with the film are the 2 superfluous characters...

I don't have any particular issue with Elijah Wood's or Mark Ruffalo's performance, they do good work. The problem I have is how useless their characters are to the story. I think that the purpose of Patrick's attempt to steal Joel's relationship is intended to show us that it's not what you say or do that creates love, but it is who you are. Yet I don't think they spend enough time on this sub-plot to fully develop that idea. Their relationship is just too far off on the periphery of the main story line, so it doesn't work. On the flip side, while Patrick's story is underdeveloped, Stan doesn't even have one. It's like he's only there to delay the interaction between Dr. Mierzwiak and Mary. He should have been written out of the film because he served no purpose. However including some extra characters that add annoyance instead of more interesting stories doesn't hurt Eternal Sunshine that much. It is still a brilliantly told story. The effects of slowly erasing the memories is so perfectly done. I love how, at first, we see minor things erasing and then slowly entire structures are disintegrating and peoples' faces are being wiped away. They use so many interesting methods: from simple darkness fading things out of our view, to blurring, and even CGI dismantling of things one board at a time. Despite some minor complaints, I found this to be an excellent film, and one I'll enjoy watching again to see what little details I missed the first time.

With a terrific premise this easily makes this my favorite Jim Carey film to date. This is the story of Joel and Clementine.  They are the classic mismatched couple.  He's reserved, she's wild and outrageous. The two of them have gone through a bad breakup and Clementine has gone and had all memories of Joel removed from her brain because she can no longer stand him. The procedure is done by a local doctor who specializes in the removal of painful memories.  When Joel finds this out he decides to erase her back, mainly out of bitterness.  But then in the middle of the procedure he changes his mind and does everything he can think of to hold onto the memories of Clementine even as they are being completely deleted from his head.



The casting in the film is interesting  Jim Carrey plays the quiet and reserved character of Joel and conceals his manic tendencies flawlessly.  Kate Winslet on the other hand is allowed to run wild with the unconventional character of Clementine.  It works wonderfully and the two have a very real and earned chemistry.  It's important to the story that we can not only see them work together but we can see why they broke apart and it's all there up on the screen.  They are backed up by a very solid cast  Kirsten Dunst is the slightly flakey secretary with a crush on the doctor in charge of the procedure.  Tom Wilkinson in the doctor role is nicely understated and much more vulnerable than these sorts of roles tend to be.  Elijah Wood's role as a mischievous little scumbag plays nicely against his innocent look.  The only cast member really doing his standard routine is Mark Ruffalo playing the slightly awkward sort of character he that he has played on a few occasions.



This movie easily could have leapt into the realm of sci-fi movies like Total Recall with elaborate devices and what is reality type twists.  But rather than walk that very well  used path, Kaufman and Gondry take the low-tech approach.  The machine used to wipe Joel's memory looks like somebody put it together in a garage it wasn't very high tech looking at all.  And while the story does toy with reality from Joel's perspective it's never played as a trick on the audience.  Joel's mind (where a large part of the film is set) is mainly just him wandering through his own memories rather than some sort of elaborate fantasy world.  In fact Gondry uses the simplest possible visuals to relay ideas rather than dipping into the well of crazy images.  It keeps the concept from taking over the story and allows it to be all about the characters.  It also touches lightly on the question of whether or not we, and the connections we have with people, are more than just the sum of our memories.  It's a rather deep concept and the movie does have its point of view on the matter but this point is not constantly in your face.  In fact it's never even spoken about directly by the characters, but it's a notion that underlies much of the movie.



It can take a little time to really accept the movie on its own terms just because it bucks so many of the ideas the audience would already have about a movie dealing with memory loss.  Also it does take some time for the story to really kick in and feel like it's going somewhere, though by the end it is clear why the movie had to start the way it does.  This makes the first 20 minutes or so work in hindsight if not completely successful upon the initial viewing.  The film comes together as a delightful way to tell a love story with a sci-fi twist.

It is like "Total Recall" (1990) in reverse, where instead of trying to add memories that never occurred, this movie toys with a procedure that can erase your memory of a given individual. Carrey's character Joel is undergoing this procedure, but decides partway through that he wants out. Since the procedure takes place in a comatose state, this is not an option. This causes the majority of the movie to take place in a dreamlike sequence. Much like a dream, events superimpose themselves, and passing through familiar doorways lead to illogical places. There was no predicting what would happen next because anything could happen next. And then when Joel decides he wants out, it becomes like being in a dream that you know you are dreaming. This is what "Nightmare on Elm Street"(1984) would be like if it were simply "Dream on Elm Street." Then to add to an already dizzying tale, halfway through the movie an unexpected twist occurs in a sub-plot that you are unaware even exists outside the dream sequence. The movie explores themes such as, of course, memory, true love and destiny. I thought the editing was fantastic, and am surprised to see it did not garner much attention. Fortunately it was recognized by fellow editors, it received a nomination at the American Cinema Editors awards. A great movie to watch,--it's different, it's philosophical, it's fun, and it's entertaining. What more can you ask for in a movie?

Not one to enjoy romances, I went into Eternal Sunshine apprehensively-- and I recommend it the same way-- but it's a pleasant, genuine, and legitimately lovable film that capably pulls the audience into the world it has created. Sure, it's a schmaltzy movie that's definitely got love as one of its main themes, but among those themes are people's interactions, shyness, how the mind works, and memories. It's a very nostalgic film (which I have to fault it for), but it's undoubtedly one of the most watchable romances I've ever seen. 

ETOTSP is about a man (Jim Carrey) whose ex-girlfriend (Kate Winslet) gets a medical procedure to wipe her mind of all memories of him, so he does the same. I cannot find a problem with the premise, as it's one of the most original takes on a typically repetitive genre that you can find. I could probably pick apart some logical inconsistencies (when their minds are erased, how do they erase single memories? Are there just gaps that they can't go back to? All memories are interconnected), but I'm going to do something completely out of character and not be a stickler for plot holes (even though there are several). Like... wouldn't the people notice after a while that they had enormous swaths of their memories missing? Fuck it, I didn't tear Total Recall apart, so I won't do it to this either.

Although reading the synopsis might make you think otherwise, most of the film is spent on the procedure itself, and Carrey's memories about Winslet and them being erased. It's a very entertaining and moving series of scenes, and the way the memories blend into each other is definitely one of the visual feats of the century. Although I had some problems when it came to the scenes outside of his mind (featuring Kirsten Dunst's 'acting'), it held up well enough to be highly enjoyable.

I do love it when a movie comes full circle like it does in ESOTSM-- but unfortunately, I don't want to spoil the ending, so I can't rant about how much I enjoyed it. But I will say this-- no matter how the rest of the movie was, the end of it can really make or break the rest of the film. Salmon Fucking on the Yemen could have been just mediocre, but the last 20 minutes merited a 2/10. The conclusion to Return of the King basically destroyed the rest of the film. But at the other end of the spectrum, you have a movie like this: It starts out slow, but builds up and up and up until it finally peaks... just before you hit the end credits. This leaves the audience wanting more, and is a very powerful filmmaking tool.

Carrey is unexpectedly good as the star of the show, leading me to believe that he might actually be better as a serious and darkly comic actor than the bombastic nutball he usually plays. Winslet, meanwhile, was my favorite part of the movie, as she completely embodied her role as an impulsive, thrill-seeking, hair color-changing girl who doesn't really know what she wants out of life. Unlike the typical romance, it actually got me to root for the main characters and hope that they would end up together, which is a feat that few films can accomplish.

Final Score for Eternal Sunshine: 7/10 stars. It loses something to the lightweight and undemanding foundation it's built on, but really, it's what it does with its flimsy premise that counts. It features spellbinding performances, agreeable dialogue, some interesting subplots, and some genuinely funny moments. This is the thinking man's romantic comedy, in that it's not too much of either. Although it often tries to be far deeper than it really is, it still deserves the recognition it has gotten for being one of Carrey's best movies.

ETERNAL SUNSHINE's narrative is essentially a love story told backwards. It deals with the traditional problem of reverse narrative in a new way. The traditional problem is that if the audience already knows the ending (bitter breakup), then telling the story in reverse asks the audience the question of "is it worth it?" as we watch the story back to the beginning (falling in love). This intellectualizes the experience rather than giving us dramatic action. ETERNAL SUNSHINE deals with this problem of intellectualization by giving the protagonist an active role in the reverse narrative. Joel is able to interact with his old memories to try to stop the process of erasing; this attempt to escape is the major sub-plot of the film. The catharsis of the audience comes with his rediscovery of his love for Clementine as they try to escape together. They fail to escape at the climax of this sub-plot and his memory is erased. But the lovers meet again by fate and once again fall in love. This fake climax of the main love-story plot is placed at the beginning of the film and again at the end of the film - the audience realizes the despite losing all their memory, the lovers meet and fall in love again. If the film ended there, it would have been a good film, and the central idea would have been "Love happens because of fate". But the problem would have been that Joel went through this huge journey of discovery and change but that all seems to go to waste if fate was just going to put them together again - he needs to be the one making an active choice that demonstrates his internal change at climax. The real climax of ETERNAL SUNSHINE comes out of the reversal at the end, in which the Joel and Clementine discover their bitter past and must choose whether or not to commit despite their past. This resurfaces Joel's inner journey. He and she choose to commit, completing Joel's journey of internal change with an external action. The central idea now becomes "Love happens because of fate but it will only result in a happy relationship with open acceptance of each other and the painful compromises that come with love". This real climax fueled by true character change, dilemma and choice is what makes the film great. The climax completes the audience catharsis experienced through Joel's rediscovery of love; as a result he wins the girl and we are touched by a great story.

Michael Gondry is a highly stylized director, sort of the like the early Tim Burton but with a plushy, crafts class aesthetic heavily mixed in.  He is deliberately kitschy in a unique way that fits the quirky demeanor of his characters and the fantastical scenarios they find themselves in.  Those characters and scenarios come courtesy of the highly original, Oscar-winning screenplay by Charlie Kaufman, continuing his streak of extreme originality, originality that benefits from a willingness to dare what anyone sensible person would not.  
The story is of a relationship between a nebbish man (Jim Carrey) and an impulsive woman (Kate Winslet), but after a fight, she has the memory of him erased from her mind, and he follows suit, but in the process, he begins to regret it, fighting against the procedure in his mind.  This story is told non-linearly and like the best nonlinear stories, it becomes a wildly fun game of keeping up and connecting the pieces.  With the pre-established structure and revelations in mind, repeat viewings have much ready to offer as well.
Jim Carrey has had some very funny comedic performance in THE MASK and LEMONY SNICKET'S A SERIES OF UNFORTUNATE EVENTS, but he's never been much of an actor.  He has a tendency to mug clownishly and his performances are usually lacking in sincerity.  But not this time.  Here, even with his comedic sequences, he finally shows a real performance with finesse and authenticity.  In one of the most odd matches of movie couples, he shows great chemistry with Kate Winslet, and hers is very fun to watch as she plays an impulsive, loud, irritable and quirky archetype of a bookstore girl, and it is quite far from anything else she's done.  
ETERNAL SUNSHINE OF THE SPOTLESS MIND is not for everyone.  It's incredibly bizarre, and for some, maybe offputting even.  As Carrey and Winslet race through his mind from the memory erasers, there are plenty of oddities, including erased memories with faceless personages, and a very funny but strange childhood memory where Winslet becomes Carrey's mother's friend, and Carrey as his child-sized self.
Most surprisingly though is how it all works.  The story is happening on many levels; the memory erasing process that takes us through the central relationship in reverse, the dysfunctional relationships between the operators performing the procedure on Carrey from outside his mind, and the reuniting of persons even after the memories are gone; and yet, even as it's all blended together, the flow is consistent, clear and gripping.

Not only is it the absolute best Jim Carrey film, as well as among Kate Winslet's greatest roles, with a fantastic cast of supporting roles, but it's still one of the greatest films within the last decade, an instant classic of a romance story that's both funny, heartfelt, and sometimes heartbreaking. Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind is a true gem in terms of writing, editing, performance, and presentation, with a daringly original concept that is executed brilliantly, and leaves you with an ending so satisfying you won't know what hit you until it's over.

Jim Carrey and Kate Winslet have amazing chemistry and you find yourself rooting for them to win their game of mental hide and seek. The world of memories is intriguing and sometimes a little disturbing but it gets the point across in a unique way. It takes the idea of the original love story and skews the timeline and universe, giving us a fresh look on a worn out narrative. The film itself is as unforgettable as Clementine is to Joel. Give it a watch. You won't regret it.

I had already seen Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind a couple years back when I was in high school. BUT I came across the movie today on Instant Netflix when I was scouring the site for something to watch on the treadmill. I fell in love with the story of Joel and Clementine as I walked three miles.

I have really been through a lot with relationships since my first viewing of the film and I needed that maturity to truly understand what the characters were going through. The love story in ESSM is not some over the top drawn out ordeal (like you usually see in Hollywood), it's an everyday common type of love between two everyday common type of people. It is something that is easy to relate to and will bring up feelings. 

I give this movie the highest possible rating I can: 10/10 or 5 fives stars.
Any movie that can make me a fan of a love story must really be good. I encourage whoever is reading this to get up and go watch it.
